repnme.cdata!:
Easing Armenia's transition to a
            market economy

abstracts.cdata!:
With independence in 1991, Armenia
            suffered a severe economic contraction. Between 1990 and
            1993, GDP dropped by more than 50 percent. This led to
            hyperinflation, a budget deficit that reached a high of 55
            percent, factory closures, little electricity supply, and
            large-scale emigration. About 80 percent of the population
            survived on humanitarian assistance and more than half the
            population lived below the poverty line.

docna.cdata!: Transicion de Armenia hacia una economia de mercado

display_title.display_title:
Easing Armenia's transition
            to a market economy : Transicion de Armenia hacia una
            economia de mercado

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rehabilitation Credit
            Project for Armenia are as follows: overall outcome of the
            project was rated highly satisfactory, and the performance
            of the Bank and Borrower also rated highly satisfactory.
            Some of the lessons learned from the project are: 1) while
            it is commonplace to emphasize the importance of recipient
            commitment and ownership, the lesson from this project is
            that neither of these is likely to be satisfactory if the
            recipient does not understand the project in more than a
            superficial way. The Government of Armenia's commitment
            to the reform process and this project were the result of a
            deep understanding of the reforms, including the inevitable
            short-run costs; 2) adequate institutional support was a
            necessary condition for the success of the project; 3) most
            of the delays which took place in the project, including
            privatization, were largely due to difficulties in designing
            and implementing a consistent set of laws and procedures.
            Given the involvement of Parliament in such a process,
            either less ambitious time tables or more active
            participation of members of Parliament from the beginning is
            required; and 4) another lesson is the need to recognize the
            interdependency of social and economic policies. Although
            this has been rectified in the structural adjustment credit,
            insufficient attention was placed on social issues in the
            Rehabilitation Credit, despite the widespread poverty, large
            declines in life expectancy, and deterioration of the
            education system. There is wide agreement that the future of
            Armenia depends on its human resources, given its lack of
            natural resources. Accordingly, the success of any economic
            reform program will depend greatly on social reform and rehabilitation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rehabilitation Credit Project will:
            (a) support the Government's reform program to
            stabilize the economy and create the conditions for a
            resumption of growth and an improvement in living standards;
            (b) provide foreign exchange for the purchase of critical
            imports, particularly for the private sector; (c) provide
            budgetary support, especially for the strengthening of the
            social safety net for the most vulnerable groups; (d)
            provide a framework for urgently needed financial assistance
            from other donors.  The program includes policies that: (a)
            promote the development of competitive markets and of the
            private sector, through privatization, liberalization and
            regulatory reforms; (b) result in improved financial
            discipline for enterprises and banks; and (c) improve the
            targeting of the social safety net to the most needy.
